ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SCENARIO AND RESPONSE POLICIES
The Indorama Ventures Olefins, LLC (IVOL) - Westlake, Louisiana is a chemical manufacturing facility and was acquired in 2015 from Occidental Chemicals. IVOL completed a large-scale construction revamp of the asset and began production 2018. The site has a long-standing pledge to operate in a manner that is safe for workers, the public and the environment. IVOL has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at the Westlake facility. This responsibility will continue to be exhibited by putting resources into assets for accident prevention. Example of this includes training the workforce and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to execute sensible controls to forestall predictable releases of hazardous substances. Nonetheless, if a release occurs, our trained workforce will respond to, control and contain the release.
DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES:
IVOL is situated at 4300 Hwy 108, Westlake, Louisiana 70669. The site makes ethylene as a primary product and several other byproducts. The site contains 1 toxic regulated chemical and 22 regulated flammable chemicals. The toxic chemical is anhydrous ammonia. The flammable chemicals are Acetylene, 1,3-Butadiene, Butane, 1-Butene, Butene, 2-Butene-cis, 2-Butene-trans, Ethane, Ethylene, Hydrogen, Isobutane, Isopentane, Methane, 1,3-Pentadiene, Pentane, 1-Pentene, 2-Pentene, (E)-, Propadiene, Propane, Propylene, Propyne, and Vinyl Acetylene.
Not all of these chemicals are handled individually at concentrations above their threshold quantity.  Many of them are combined in a feed or process stream with other non-RMP regulated chemicals.
GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS
Following is a synopsis of the general accident prevention program set up at IVOL. Processes at the site are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation and are subject to the OS

HA PSM standard. This outline tends to address each of the OSHA PSM elements and depicts the management system set up to implement the accident prevention program.
Employee Participation:
IVOL has developed a written action plan for employee participation in all aspects of its Process Safety Management and Risk Management Programs. The site employees are involved in the PHA reviews, Operating Procedures, Incident Investigations, work permits and many other PSM programs.  IVOL ensures that all employees have access to PHAs and other process safety management information.
Process Safety Information:
IVOL maintains a compilation of current and accurate written safety information to identify and understand the hazards of the process. This includes information pertaining to hazards of regulated substances, the technology of the process, and the equipment in the process. 
With respect to the hazards of regulated substances, there are Safety Data Sheets (SDS) which discuss the physical properties of the chemicals, exposure hazards, the required personal protective equipment and the appropriate first aid and emergency treatment for exposure.
With respect to the technology of the process, there a description of process chemistry, safe upper and lower limits of temperature and pressure and analysis of consequences of deviation.
With respect to the equipment in the process, there is information such as materials of construction, diagrams of the piping and instrumentation, safety systems and design codes.
Process Hazard Analysis:
IVOL has performed process hazard analysis on the process to identify the potential hazards, the adequacy of the engineering and administrative controls and the mitigations systems used to minimize those hazards. The Site utilizes the HAZOP methodology, a recognized and generally accepted method, for identifying and evaluating hazards in the process.  The Site assigns employees to the HAZOP team who are knowledgeable in the HAZOP methodology and the sp

ecific process.  The HAZOP team develops recommendations to reduce the potential hazards which, if approved, are implemented within a reasonable period of time. Hurricanes and inclement weather are not investigated in the PHAs; however, Indorama does have a Hurricane Procedure and implements this procedure under the threat of a hurricane and inclement weather.
Operating Procedures
IVOL maintains written operating procedures that are developed in consultation with operators to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities associated with a covered process.  The procedures address steps for all operating phases, safety systems, control measures and precautions to prevent exposures to process hazards. The procedures are reviewed and revised periodically to ensure their accuracy and completeness.
Training
IVOL provides initial training as well as refresher training to employees to assure that the required level of skills and knowledge are maintained. The training emphasizes safety and health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  All operators receive periodic refresher training.
Mechanical Integrity
IVOL has developed practices and procedures that make up the mechanical integrity program including pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems.  The site has also developed Mechanical Integrity Procedures (MIP) for the emergency shutdown system controls. The rotating equipment and non-safety system Instrumentation also have a developed mechanical integrity and maintenance strategy program. The programs are comprised of well-trained personnel who follow maintenance, testing and inspection procedures that ensure proper function of process equipment.
Management of Change
IVOL has established and implemented written procedures and an electronic system to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and any changes to the facility that affect a covered process. The procedures assure that, pr

ior to any change, the following issues are considered:  the technical basis for the proposed change, its impact on safety and health, any modifications to operating procedures, the necessary time period for the change, and any authorization requirements.  Employees involved in operating a process, as well as maintenance and contract employees whose job will be affected, are informed of and trained in the change.  If necessary, the process safety information and operating procedures are updated as a part of the management of change process.
Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
IVOL performs pre-startup safety reviews when an addition or a modification to the facility is made and the MOC evaluation designates a PSSR is required.  The pre-startup safety review confirms, prior to the introduction of chemicals, that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; and training of employees affected by modifications is complete.
Compliance Audits
IVOL performs audits of its compliance with the provisions of its Process Safety Management Program.  A team comprised of employees from the Corporate PSM department and other Indorama facilities, with appropriate knowledge of audit techniques and process safety experience, conduct audits every three years to verify that the procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed.  The findings of the audit team are reviewed, and appropriate corrective actions are implemented and tracked until resolved.
Incident Investigation
IVOL promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards thes

e results to site management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.
Safe Work Practices
IVOL employs a hot work permit program for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process (hot work generally involves electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing or similar spark producing operations).  If any hot work is performed near a covered process, the site issues a permit that documents the fire prevention and protection requirements for the operation, the date authorized for hot work, and the object on which the work is performed. Hot work permits are kept on file until the work is complete.
Contractors 
IVOL has developed procedures for selecting and ensuring that contractors are competent and knowledgeable and can safely perform their work. The site provides information to contractors about the hazards that may be present in the work area and have developed appropriate safe work practices.  The site also evaluates the safety performance and programs of the contractors as a part of their continued employment.
CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The processes at IVOL have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors.
In addition to the accident prevention program activities, IVOL has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following t

ypes of safety features are used in various processes:
Release Detection
1.  Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
2.  Leak Detection and Repair Program.
Release Containment/Control
1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases.
2. Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated).
3. Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)
4. Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases.
5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pump).
6. Atmospheric relief devices.
Release Mitigation
1. Fire suppression and extinguishing systems.
2. Deluge systems for specific equipment.
3. Trained emergency response personnel.
4. Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
5. Mobile fire-fighting equipment.
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
IVOL maintains a written emergency response program along with an onsite Emergency Response Team, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation. It also includes notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, IVOL has procedures that address the maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment. The emergency response team receives training in industrial firefighting, high angle rescue, confined space rescue, HAZMAT, spill response and emergency first aid. The emergency response

program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to site processes or other site facilities. The emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.
Representatives from IVOL attend periodic meetings of the Calcasieu Parish Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness (OHSEP), which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. IVOL has around-the-clock communications capability with Southwest Louisiana Mutual Aid Association. IVOL will provide assistance to community and industry response agencies as requested via the Southwest Louisiana Mutual Aid Association and Calcasieu Parish Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness (OHSEP). The OHSEP has the capability of notifying the public and industry of any incidents that may affect them, including security and weather notifications. The Southwest Louisiana Mutual Aid Association shares information between facilities and has a communication network for notifying neighboring facilities of incidents that may affect them.
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
IVOL keeps records for all accidental chemical releases that occur at the facility. The site has had one accidental releases from covered processes in the past five years that resulted in one injury and significant property damage on site. The event did not cause any known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
There are several planned improvements at IVOL to reduce the on and offsite impacts of hazardous processes. Selected ongoing projects include improvements controls on fired heaters such as the cracking furnaces and improvements in relief system design. There is continual commitment to implement changes, when identified, that will improve the safety of employees and neighbors of the IVOL
